article.title: Genome and clonal hematopoiesis stability contrasts with immune, cfDNA, mitochondrial, and telomere length changes during short duration spaceflight
funding: Leukemia and Lymphoma Society (Grants No. LLS 9238-16 and MCL7001-18)
National Institutes of Health (Grants No. P01CA214274, R01CA249054 and R01MH117406)
NASA(Grants No. 80NSSC19K0432, 80NSSC22K0254, NNH18ZTT001N-FG2, NNX13AE45G, NNX14AH50G, NNX17AB26G)
article.abstract: The Inspiration4 (I4) mission, the first all-civilian orbital flight mission, investigated the physiological effects of short-duration spaceflight through a multi-omic approach.

sections.introduction: Human spaceflight frequency has increased over the last decade, and with it, our grasp of its effects on human physiology.
sections.methods: This study was completed following appropriate ethical guidelines according to the Declaration of Helsinki, ICHGCP, and local regulations, as applicable, from each potential subject or each subject's legally authorized representative prior to participating in the research study.
sections.results: We first examined DNA from dried blood spots (DBS), which were collected from the I4 crew members before (L-92, L-44, L-3), during (FD1, FD2, FD3), and after (R + 1, R + 45, R + 82) spaceflight, from which DNA was isolated, and telomere length measured via multiplexed quantitative PCR (MMqPCR).
sections.discussion: The I4 mission is the first study to date to analyze the effect of short duration spaceflight on civilians using a comprehensive multi-omics approach.

experimental_factors.treatment: microgravity, space radiation, immune system perturbations
experimental_factors.treatment_raw: microgravity, space radiation, immune system perturbations

article.insights_summary: The I4 mission studied the effects of short-duration spaceflight on civilians using a multi-omics approach, finding telomere length dynamics and immune cell gene expression adaptations to spaceflight. The study provides valuable insights into the physiological consequences of short-duration spaceflight.
article.acknowledgments: This study was supported by the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, the National Institutes of Health, the WorldQuant Foundation, and NASA.
